race.name: Gravel Unravel - Bon Jon Pass Out
race.display_name: Gravel Unravel - Bon Jon Pass Out

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Olympic Peninsula. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional WA event. Mountain terrain with remote location and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Unravel - Bon Jon Pass Out is a regional event in Washington—mountain terrain with significant elevation. The Olympic Peninsula is scenic, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional WA mountain gravel race. Worth it for WA/Northwest riders. Not worth traveling far for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to WA—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better WA races: Check regional options.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Quilcene has limited lodging. Plan ahead or stay in nearby towns.
logistics.food: Quilcene has limited dining. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: Camping at Lake Leland Amphitheater (10 min drive from Worthington Park) for Friday/Saturday nights, including RV sites in town

guide_variables.race_name: Gravel Unravel - Bon Jon Pass Out

non_negotiables.why: Pacific Northwest weather is variable with rain possible.
Olympic Peninsula mountains require sustained effort.
Limited aid stations and remote location require self-sufficiency.

topics.weather: Riding in variable Pacific Northwest weather

marketplace_variables.race_name: Gravel Unravel - Bon Jon Pass Out

logistics.explanation: Worthington Park start/finish keeps things simple, but Ted King notes "there is essentially zero cell coverage on the course" forcing offline GPS downloads. King benefited from "staying on site a day before" to scout finish line positioning, while organizers warn RideWithGPS surfaces are incorrect. Limited 400-rider field helps organization but navigation prep becomes mandatory.

length.explanation: Ted King took "approaching two hours" to climb Bon Jon Pass, with "most of the climbing done by the half-way point" before "motoring to the finish line." The 2024 long course was shortened from 80 to 55 miles due to severe weather, showing distance flexibility when conditions demand it. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: King describes "a rough double-track section around mile 25" as "a 4x4 track" with "plenty of whoops and dips" over "nearly three rough miles." The technical challenge peaks on "screaming fast descents with wheel-eating potholes which would end your day badly if you weren't paying close attention." Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: The Bon Jon Pass climb gains 4,000 feet from sea level in a sustained effort that King calls "just so long!" The long course forces riders to "climb Bon Jon again" - hitting the pass twice. King set his "best 60-minute power for the year" on the opening climb that "shredded the peloton to just four riders." Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Weather varies dramatically from "showers and even sleet" in 2024 to "good conditions" in 2025, though riders still faced "cloud and fog at high elevations." King experienced "cold fingers" affecting bike handling, while elevation changes create "an entirely different climate" requiring careful clothing strategy for the 4,000-foot elevation range. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Starting from Quilcene at sea level and topping out "a bit shy of 4,000 feet" on Bon Jon Pass means zero altitude considerations. This is pure climbing volume without thin air effects. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: King describes reaching "a remote valley in the far reaches of the course, which was bucolic and just stunning" where he and his companion "were both shivering from the long cold descent." Zero cell coverage adds isolation factor, while June timing hits peak rhododendron blooms "spotlighted against the deep green background of the forest."

prestige.explanation: Ted King acknowledges "the field wasn't huge at Bon Jon Pass Out" in this 400-rider regional event. King calls it "very grassroots" with "no showiness to this event, just people out having a good time on two wheels." Limited to Pacific Northwest appeal despite quality organization.

race_quality.explanation: Close finishes show competitive depth - the long course was "decided by just a few seconds" with winner Tyler Klansnic beating Ben Shauland by two seconds after nearly five hours. Aid stations and mechanical support cover basics, though weather forced course modification in 2024 from 80 to 55 miles.

experience.explanation: Jan Heine found "just the right combination of professional organization and down-to-earth vibe" that "felt like racing way back, when cycling was a tiny sport." King stayed "literally about 20 steps from the back door" to the start line at Worthington mansion, with post-race "hot food, beer garden, and awards" maintaining small-town atmosphere.

community.explanation: Heine describes the welcoming atmosphere: "you just assumed that anybody showing up was a friend, or would become one." Organizers Lorrie and Buck bring "infectious enthusiasm," while proceeds benefit Quilcene Historical Museum. King notes the "common thread to gravel riders" creating grassroots camaraderie without pretension.

field_depth.explanation: King's early breakaway of "just four riders taking pulls" after twenty minutes shows how quickly the field splits on Bon Jon Pass. With 400 riders across three distances and multiple age groups, competitive depth stays thin despite quality like King's presence and close elite finishes. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: $60-80 entry fees include RFID timing that delivered a two-second photo finish after five hours, aid stations with mechanical support, and post-race food. King consumed "all of my nutrition and never wanted more or less" from on-course support. Proceeds support local nonprofits adding community value beyond racing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-100. King's accommodation at "the historic Worthington mansion" put him "20 steps" from the start line, while camping options keep costs down. Quilcene location avoids resort pricing while staying accessible from Seattle metro without flight requirements. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

citations.label: renehersecycles.com: Ted Kings Impressions From Bon Jon Pass

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Gravel Unravel - Bon Jon Pass Out gravel race Quilcene

videos.title: Racing the Bon Jon Pass Out
videos.description:
I do lots of small events, but big events are fewer and further between on my calendar. I headed out to to Seattle and then the tiny town of Quilcene for the Bon Jon Pass Out gravel race courtesy of my friends at Rene Herse Cycles with the invitation.
With some inclement weather in store, we didn't know what to expect, climbing from sea level to just shy of 4,000 feet elevation, especially given the forecast for lightning, hail, and worse!
But the brave souls toed the startline and we had a great time all the same.

Post ride write up: https://www.renehersecycles.com/ted-kings-impressions-from-bon-jon-pass/

Event: Gravel Unravel's Bon Jon Pass Out
Town: Quilcene, WA
Population: 610

Bike: @CannondaleBicycles71 SuperSix EVO SE size 58
Drivetrail: @SRAM 46 x 10-50t, SRAM AXS Red Shifters/Calipers
Wheels: @zippspeed Firecrest 303
Tires: @ReneHerseCycles Manastash Ridge 700x44, Endurance Plus
Nutrition: @untappedmaple 2 bottles Mapleaid, 8 Salted UnTapped packets
@WHOOP 4.0
@CycleOpsPowerCycling with the bike rack to help me get to the airport!

videos.curation_reason: Professional cyclist's detailed first-person race recap with course preview and terrain analysis.

videos.title: Gravel Unravel
videos.description: Gravel Unravel is a 3-race endurance bicycle race/ride on the gravel roads of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State.

videos.title: Bon Jon Pass Single-track Loop
videos.description:
It's been a while! Covid and everything got in the way. Welcome to my latest adventure. This is a 2 night/3 day route with shelters along the way so you don't even need a tent! 


Route info here: https://ridewithgps.com/routes/30068829


Trails ridden:
3 o'clock ridge: https://www.trailforks.com/trails/three-o-clock-ridge-137577/

Lower Dungeness River: https://www.trailforks.com/trails/lower-dungeness-river/
Gold Creek Trail: https://www.trailforks.com/trails/gold-creek-trail-68304/
Sleepy Hollow Trail #852: https://www.trailforks.com/trails/sleepy-hollow-tr-852/
Lower Big Quilcene: https://www.trailforks.com/trails/sleepy-hollow-tr-852/


Music:
Take your time -Dan Lebowitz (courtesy of youtube studio)
All other instrumental music performed by myself

videos.title: 2021-05-01 Hoh-ly Roller/Gravel Unravel Series
videos.description:
My second official gravel bike ride of the year was in Forks, WA.  Quite different from the previous one in Ephrata which was a bunch of open spaces with consistent climbs (which were mostly on the road, by the way).  Whereas that one was farm lands for miles, this one was in the forest with views of trees for miles.  For me, it was the hardest effort in a while.  Although we only did what was officially billed as 26 miles (turned out to be 32) and supposedly 3,000 feet of climbing (which turned out to be around 3,800), this was undoubtedly a sufferfest.  To get that much elevation over a short distance meant climbs of 15 - 20% for extended periods over loose gravel fire roads, with the occasional muddy stretch.  Yes, we enjoyed being outdoors and the camaraderie among riders was cool.  Weather was perfect (forecasted rain but it quickly changed to dry, cloudy with sunbreaks - we averaged high 40's to low 50's, which was perfect climbing weather).  I'm not sure if I'm signing up for something like that again, though.
I trained specifically for this event for just around 6 weeks - even replaced my whole drivetrain to get that really low gearing for those steep climbs.  Was it worth it?  Well, Y.O.L.O., right?  
Every new piece of equipment worked fantastic...Shimano GRX 2-11 (42T)all the way, except for that GoPro mount which snapped (more in the video).  Two of them, too....

Here's more info on the ride series in case you're interested in participating in the second or third one.  I'm probably not going...
https://peninsulaadventuresports.com/events/quilcene-gravel-unravel/

quotes.text: I'm approaching 4,000 ft in altitude which is pretty impressive because I started the day at sea level and I've basically exclusively been climbing - what 15 miles in approaching 3500 ft this is a challenging race.
The name bonjon pass out is quite fitting - if you're going to be climbing for the better part of what an hour and a half, you kind of want to pass out when you get up this high.

key_challenges.name: Bon Jon Pass climb
key_challenges.description: Starting at sea level and climbing exclusively to approaching 4,000 ft altitude, with one rider noting they were approaching 3500 ft at 15 miles in. Riders describe this as climbing for the better part of an hour and a half.

key_challenges.name: 15 to 18 gravel climbs
key_challenges.description: Multiple steep gravel climbs throughout the course that cause many people to walk, though some riders complete without walking.

terrain_notes.text: The ground is more loamy and soft on the west coast, with moss encroaching the middle of paved roads and plants growing out of the pavement. Expect muddy conditions.
Dusty conditions on climbs, with riders needing masks due to dust.

gear_mentions.text: 700x44 Manastash Ridge tires in endurance plus casing recommended for the softer, loamy terrain and unfamiliar sharp rocks.
Maximum 30 chainring with 42 cassette for the steep climbing sections.

race_day_tips.text: Prepare for weather - expect 40-something degrees at the start with precipitation possible. Bring layers including ultralight jacket for the temperature variation from sea level to 4000 ft.
Secure your equipment well - multiple riders experienced GoPro mounting failures on the rough gravel terrain.

additional_quotes.text: I can honestly say this is the hardest ride I've ever done over the past two years
The important thing is we made it, we did not walk we did not, a lot of people want a lot of people walk we did not walk those 15 to 18 climbs on the gravel

rider_intel.search_text: The Gravel Unravel - Bon Jon Pass Out in Quilcene, WA features extreme elevation gain starting at sea level and climbing to nearly 4,000 feet. The signature Bon Jon Pass climb hits 3,500 feet by mile 15, requiring an hour and a half of sustained climbing. Riders face 15-18 gravel climbs throughout the course, with many walking sections. Terrain includes loamy, soft ground with moss-covered roads and muddy conditions. Weather can include precipitation with temperatures starting in the 40s. The Pacific Northwest setting offers mountain views and pine forests. Riders recommend 700x44 tires in endurance casing for the sharp rocks and soft terrain, plus low gearing like 30x42 for the steep sections. Equipment security is important due to rough conditions causing mounting failures.
